results.title: Hedwig and the angry inch
results.creator_credit: Killer Films, New Line Cinema, Pamela Koffler, Katie Roumel, Christine Vachon and John Cameron Mitchell
results.brief_description: Written, directed and starring John Cameron Mitchell, and based on his award-winning Off-Broadway musical, “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” is a startling and moving musical about difference and love. Hedwig started life as a boy in East Germany but when he falls in love with an American GI, he makes the ultimate sacrifice, by cutting off his genitalia to an “angry inch”. Unfortunately, all the GI offers Hedwig back in the USA is life in a trailer park. Hedwig uses his ample imagination to write songs but credit for them is taken by his nemesis (and one true love), Tommy Gnosis (Michael Pitt II). While Hedwig is forced to tour second-rate restaurants and night clubs, Tommy Gnosis has become a huge star. Hedwig won’t rest till Tommy acknowledges both his love and his debt. Featuring an electrifying performance by Mitchell in the title role, and a wonderful set of songs which manage to pay homage to both punk and old theatrical musicals, “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” is a defiant celebration of independence and gender confusion. Made on a miniscule budget, the film boasts inventive art direction and design. Mitchell’s perseverance and courage has paid off. The film has won numerous international film awards including a special prize at the Berlin Film Festival 2001 and the Audience Award and the Best Director Award at the Sundance Film Festival, 2001.

results.title: Hector goes to play ball
results.creator_credit: Crawford Productions, Lindsay Parker and Phillip Mark-Law
results.brief_description: A fantasy which employs fun-loving Hector the Cat to teach children road safety rules. Hector is a giant cat who lives in the botanical gardens and loves to play with the children who visit him there. He leads them in an assortment of colourful games, but comes to a bad end because he forgets his road safety rules.

results.title: Hector and Milly save Uncle Tom
results.brief_description: Hector has just married Milly, and before they drive off, he checks his bride’s safety belt. Their first house guest is Uncle Tom, a silly old man lacking all road sense. It takes all Hector and Milly’s time saving him from trouble. Words and music by Charles Marawood, Damien Parer - Unit Manager. Costumed characters performed in pantomime musical style.

results.title: Hector's roadshow
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation and Ron Saunders
results.brief_description: Humour and fantasy are employed to convey an essential road safety message to young children. Kerb drill, bicycle safety and the use of seat belts are emphasized in this zany pantomine. Cast: Tony Strachan and Greg Temple. Cinematographer/Director of Photography: Edwin Scragg.

results.title: Heavy traffic
results.creator_credit: Film Creations, Steve Krantz and Ralph Bakshi
results.brief_description: Where’s it all going and where does it lead us? What is life all about? Michael, a struggling cartoonist living with his part Italian part Jewish parents is searching for artistic inspiration in the seedy environment around him - a violent, sexually perverse and polluted one. Reclusive and introspective, Michael makes an unsuccessful pitch to get his work off the ground and is forced into numerous disastrous encounters with prostitutes by friends in an attempt to prove his manhood. It’s barkeep Carole who earns his affections however as well as introducing him to a life of crime. Beginning and ending with live action, Bakshi’s film following “Fritz the cat” (1972) is mainly animated in its portrayal of a seedy, disturbing, yet artistically rich milieu of New York City circa 1970s. Cast includes: Joseph Kaufmann, Beverly Hope Atkinson, Frank DeKova, Terri Haven.

results.title: Heavy petting
results.brief_description: Using footage from Hollywood in the 50’s and 60’s and educational material from the era, known personalities reflect on what it was like to be a living, breathing, sexual being in the 1950’s or 60’s. People such as Allan Ginsberg, William Burroughs, Sandra Bernhard, Francis Fisher, Frederic Lahey, John Oates and Zoe Tamerlaine discuss issues such as; dating, masturbation, petting, falling in love, menstruation, things you did to look cool, cruising, parties, dances, teen pregnancy, STD, and all the other concerns surrounding being a teenager. Set to a soundtrack of music from the decades in question, this snappy and entertaining documentary presents the viewer with a slice of 50’s and 60’s nostalgia.

results.title: Heavy horse pull
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Beryl Fox, Don Hopkins, Ronald Squire and Roberta King
results.brief_description: A humorous documentary about horse-pulling contests in Ontario and the people who prepare for them, this film tackles heavy loads with a light touch. It travels from the farm to the contest, where excitement runs high and the quips do not lack in local colour. Photographed by Robert Fresco.

results.title: Heavenly creatures
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, Jim Booth and Peter Jackson
results.brief_description: Set in the 1950’s in New Zealand, this film is based on a true story that shocked the nation at the time. New arrival Juliet Hulme (Kate Winslet) quickly befriends the quiet Pauline Parker (Melanie Lynskey) at their conservative school in Christchurch. Although their backgrounds are very different, the two girls are both creative and intelligent writers, and form a close friendship which gradually becomes more and more obsessive. Together, they create a fantasy world peopled by characters who become very real for both of them. Their parents are increasingly disturbed by the obsessive nature of their relationship, and take steps to separate them. This leads to the girls plotting a horrendous crime to ensure they remain together.

results.title: Heaven, hell and Eldorado
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Geoffrey Barnes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Sweat of the sun, tears of the moon”.
The Amazonian jungle, the largest in the world, covers almost half of South America. For the white man the jungle is a mysterious realm, an El Dorado, that has attracted adventurers and missionaries in search of wealth and souls, ever since the time of Columbus. Jack Pizzey travels through three countries to assess the impact of loggers, gold miners, ranchers, road builders and missionaries on both the Amazonian jungle and the Indians who inhabit it. The question remains, is Western civilisation turning this Eden into Hell?

results.title: Heaven help us!
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Frank Bagnal and Robert Kingsbury
results.brief_description: There’s only one thing wrong with telephones: people use them. This film sets out to explain the simple rules of telephone etiquette with special effects and fantasy sequences. Max Meldrum plays an angel, who for some reason is in charge of heaven’s communications systems! Using a shonky business as an example, he explains the do’s and dont’s of good communication over the phone. Produced for the Australian Post Office.
